Chief Complaint:
Follow up Ultrasound/colon
History of Present Illness:
63 y/o F here for results of colon as well as labs. Colonoscopy was done and revealed multiple small mouth diverticula found in the descending and sigmoid colon as well as internal hemorrhoids grade 1. No family history of colon cancer or colon polyps.
9/3/25: Ultrasound of her abdomen reveals mildly increased liver echogenicity likely steatosis. Small echogenic focus in the gallbladder possibly a small 3 mm polyp.
8/19/25: Liver workup revealed all was negative. LFTs normal except mildly elevated ALT at 40. She does Zumba 3 times a week and she will try a High-protein, low-carb diet. She does not drink any alcohol. She has not started any new supplements or medications. Supplements she does take are apple cider vinegar, Fish oil, Magnesium, cinnamon and glucosamine. She has no family history of liver disease. Denies any IV drug use, or tattoos. She has had a blood transfusion when she was a baby in 1962. She states she feels fine and denies any GI complaints. No nausea or vomiting. No abdominal pain. No visible bleeding. No weight changes or appetite changes. No changes in her bowel movements.
Past Medical History
Medications:
levothyroxine 75 mcg TAKE ONE (1) TABLET(S) BY MOUTH ONCE A DAY.
Allergies:
Patient has no known drug allergies

Chief Complaint:
GERD/Constipation
History of Present Illness:
Ms. Clark is a 55-year-old female who presents for a new evaluation for GERD. Last seen in January 2022.  Has been seeing GI at UT Dr. Alexis Pavle.  Patient states she has been on a semaglutide since December and has been taking it for weight loss. Was going to go off in June but was started gaining weight and is still back taking it. States she has had worsening constipation and does not feel that the Trulance has been working as well. Has to take "5 tabs of the Trulance to work". Having 1 bowel movement a week. This morning she did have a bowel movement but it was loose. Taking mag citrate as needed. Also having increased reflux on the semaglutide with chest pressure and phlegm in the morning. Does drink 1 large cup of coffee in the morning no tea or soda but alcohol or wine every night. Also having lower abdominal pain and better with a bowel movement. No recent labs done in the last couple of years
Has a history of IBS constipation  She was on Linzess 145 in the past but insurance did not cover it. She has a history of periumbilical pain and this is where they did the surgery for her tubal. Stool softeners gave her gas MiraLAX gave her gas.
Review of records
--colonoscopy 5/12/2016 left-sided diverticulosis internal hemorrhoids otherwise normal colonoscopy
--KUB 5/14/2020 no obstruction moderate amount of stool throughout the ascending colon
Past Medical History
Medications:
Magnesium Citrate
Semaglutide 7.5mg
Trulance 3 mg TAKE ONE (1) TABLET(S) BY MOUTH ONCE A DAY FOR 30 DAYS. 30

Patient has no known drug allergies

Diagnoses:
Constipation by delayed colonic transit
IBS (irritable colon syndrome)
GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease)
Assessment:
Constipation. Had normal colonoscopy in May 2016. Currently taking Trulance 3 mg daily and having a bowel movement usually weekly. Requiring to take magnesium citrate to have a bowel movement or she will take "5 tabs of the Trulance". Reviewed with her that semaglutide's can worsen constipation. Can give her a trial of Linzess 290 mcg daily and prescription as well as samples were given to her. Having IBS type symptoms with lower abdominal pain but pain resolves with bowel movement. Has not had labs in years and will obtain CBC CMP as well as celiac and wheat allergy.
GERD and having increased reflux symptoms in the morning with chest pressure and phlegm. Reviewed with her foods that can increase reflux and decrease her caffeine and alcohol intake. Currently taking no medications for reflux and we will start her on Protonix 40 mg daily before breakfast. If symptoms do not improve would consider EGD
Plan:
Obtain records from UT GI Dr. Alexis Pavle
Linzess 290 mcg Take 1 capsule by mouth, on an empty stomach, at least 30 minutes before a meal, ~same time each day
pantoprazole 40 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth once a day 30 min before breakfast
Follow-up with P.A./N.P. in 3 months
Complete Blood Count (CBC) with Diff
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP)
Celiac Ab profile: tTg IgG/IgA, DGP IgG/IgA, total IgA
Wheat IgE

Chief Complaint:
constipation follow up visit
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 58 year old female here today for a follow up regarding constipation.
4/2024 ER visit for multiple BMs with blood and fainting. CT scan with ascending colitis. Discharged on Augmentin and Toradol
Hx primary immune deficiency (stable on IVIG) and hypereosinophilic syndrome.
Has in infusion 1x a month. Does have nausea around time of infusion.
Takes zofran as needed.
Linzess and Trulance have been suboptimal. Has been taking Miralax daily. Constipation has reoccurred. BMs are pebble like and every few days. Has not bad a full BM in 3 weeks. Denies hematochezia or melena. Does have abdominal cramping.
Has been trying to lose weight. Continues on Mounjaro.
She is being followed by DGD for goiter, has been having sonograms yearly.
Reports retrosternal burning and regurgitation. Takes famotidine as needed. Does report worsening GERD after GLP-1 injection. Reports decrease renal function. Had evaluation with Nephrologist and was told she was dehydrated.
She has decreased furosemide from 40 to 20mg.
She is being followed by hematology (Dr. Melissa Crawley) for elevated platelets. Pending further testing.
States was told she had Monoclonal B-cell lymphocytosis.
7/18/24 labs with increased platelets 480, and slight elevation of WBC 11.7. CMP- WNL

Diagnosis:
Abdominal pain, right lower quadrant (c)
Constipation
GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease) (e)
Assessment:
Abdominal pain: Resolved. History of ascending colitis on CT that was felt to be ischemic in etiology. No longer having abdominal pain. Constipation has worsened since starting Mounjaro. Linzess and Trulance have been suboptimal. Symptoms were controlled with Miralax and fiber. OTC products no longer working. Will start a trial of ibsrela 50mg once a day. After 2-3 days if no improvements can increase to BID dosing. She will call office if symptoms improve so medication can be sent to pharmacy. If no improvements can consider trial of Amitiza 24mcg BID.
Will continue following up with Hematologist
GERD: Symptoms occur day of and a few day after GLP-1 injection. Instead of taking famotidine as needed, will take day of injection along with 2-3 days after that. Can take as needed in between injections. Will continue to follow GERD diet.
Plan:
Provide patient with Ibsrela 50mg BID dosing (2 boxes)
Follow-up with P.A./N.P. in 3 months
GERD diet, education provided

Chief Complaint:
Blood in stool
Constipation
History of Present Illness:
39-year-old male who I saw in consultation for nausea and vomiting.
For the past 3 months has been having intermittent nausea and vomiting and has lost 25 pounds over the past 3 months. He has lethargy and fatigue and sleeps for 16 to 18 hours a day despite which he still feels fatigued. The swelling of the face and abdomen. He also has diarrhea now although he was having constipation in the past. He sweats when he eats anything.
He has vomiting 2-3 times a week which is not necessarily postprandial. He has dry heaving at night. He vomits liquids and the food that he has just eaten. It continues for about 30 minutes each time. No specific trigger for this. He has heartburn at bedtime few days a week. Has hiccups before the vomiting starts. Denies nocturnal heartburn. No dysphagia, sore throat, cough, hoarseness or globus. Does not use any tobacco products. No history of peptic ulcer disease. Takes Advil 2 tablets once a week. He was drinking 25-30 beers each week but now has cut back to 15 beers a week which he drinks over a 5-day.. Is on omeprazole OTC once a day and Zofran as needed which are not helping with the symptoms. No abdominal pain at this time. Denies early satiety. No hematemesis.
Was having constipation in the past and had a bowel movement every other day for which he took Dulcolax as needed. For the past 6 months he has been having 3-4 bowel movements a day which are usually postprandial. The stool is loose to watery. The stool volume varies. He has urgency with bowel movement. Some of the bowel movements are not postprandial. Has to strain with bowel movement at times with incomplete evacuation. Has abdominal gas and bloating. No blood in the stool or black stool. Abdominal cramps which are generalized. There is mucus in the stool and at times the stool is of narrow caliber. No lactose or gluten intolerance. No recent antibiotics or travel abroad. No sick contacts. No new medications. No family history of colitis or colon cancer. No prior colonoscopy. He does not smoke marijuana.
He has headaches and has falls which he attributes to his stumbling over something. Wife notes that he has been more irritable and his mentation is slow at times.
8/14/2023 chest x-ray and abdominal x-ray did not reveal any significant abnormality.
9/15/2025
41-year-old male who I saw in consultation for blood in stool.
8/12/2025 CMP was normal. Iron saturation 27%. Ferritin 146. CBC was normal.
He has bowel movement every 3 to 4 days and on these days he has 3-4 bowel movements a day which vary from BSS type I-II to IV. When it is the latter the stools are of narrow caliber. The stool volume is small and he has to strain with bowel movement with incomplete evacuation, abdominal gas and bloating. He has abdominal cramping which improves after bowel movement. About 2 weeks of the month there is bright red blood with his bowel movement. He takes Dulcolax laxative 3 tablets about once a week and about 12 hours later he has 4-5 watery stools which are large in volume. After these bowel movements he feels like he has completely evacuated. Denies any weight loss or loss of appetite. He had banding of hemorrhoids about 6 to 7 years ago. Mother had benign polyps in her 50s. No prior colonoscopy.
No nausea, vomiting, heartburn or dysphagia.
Past Medical History

finasteride 5 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth once a day
fluoxetine 20 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth every morning as directed
lisinopril 10 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth once a day
omeprazole 40 mg Take 1 capsule by mouth once a day
testosterone cypionate 200 mg/mL 1 intramuscularly once a week

Chief Complaint:
Abd pain/ Bloating
History of Present Illness:
Ms. Moore is a 63 year old patient who presents for a follow up evaluation.
Last Visit 3/13/2025:  Past 2 years has had:
- Intermittent LUQ pain, often when she is getting off of work as a cashier, has to stand for 4 hour shifts at a time.
- Intermittent umbilical abdominal pain, unrelated to positions/eating. Does not necessarily lead to a BM, but pain resolves for a time after having a BM, before recurring.
- Intermittent nausea/dyspepsia, any time of the day, no obvious trigger.
- Minimal breakthrough acid reflux/heart burn on Pantoprazole 40 mg in am/Pepcid Complete in the afternoon. Also frequent post-prandial burping/belching. Endorses early satiety.
- Mild intermittent constipation.
--> Treat constipation with Miralax/generic, SIBO testing, 4 hour solid phase GES.
- 3/21/2025 - TrioSmart SIBO testing- normal/negative.
Today,
- Multifactorial, but unable to follow up short-term as recommended, and unable to complete GES.
- After discussion, LUQ and umbilical abdominal pain discussed last visit seems to have resolved.
-- Notes that she is no longer working 8-hour shifts, instead doing 4-hour shifts, which seems to have made a difference.
C/o new epigastric pain,can be before work, but majority of the time it is noticeable right when getting off work, and seems to improve if she eats something.
-- Eats light breakfast 8am, then doesn't eat until 4-5 pm after work.
-- Denies frequent NSAID use, or recent antibiotics/steroids.
- Continues to have breakthrough burping symptoms on pantoprazole/famotidine.
-- Notes that she has tried and failed all over-the-counter PPI options (omeprazole, esomeprazole, lansoprazole, and rabeprazole) twice daily for over 8 weeks.
-- Has found pantoprazole the most effective in minimizing her GERD symptoms including the belching, but not completely resolve burping symptoms.
- Denies significant early satiety, but does admit to significant weight loss of around 50 pounds over 2 years, 3 years ago. For the past year her weight has been stable at around 130 lb.
-- Believes her weight loss was related to improving her diet, her prior significant symptoms with dyspepsia/indigestion, and admits a decreased appetite.

Recalled severe symptoms for 2 years treated with steroids but then her medication was stopped and she did not take anything for the next 30 or 40 years. Generally asymptomatic with very rare brbpr or diarrhea. Screening colonoscopy was normal.
She is referred today with 6 weeks of escalating diarrhea. She tells me prior to this she was having diarrhea once a week that would resolve with Imodium. 6 weeks ago her diarrhea escalated and she is now having 3 or 4 episodes daily. Rare bright red blood she thinks is related to hemorrhoids. No focal abdominal pain but she does have some cramps. She does not recall recent antibiotics but has had a worsening clinical course since a prolonged hospitalization last summer for COPD exacerbation complicated by a vocal cord paralysis that she thinks was related to intubation. She is seeing rheumatology and being referred to UT Southwestern for possible neurologic autoimmune disease. She tells me that she had recent stool studies and she was told these were consistent with ulcerative colitis although I do not have the results.

Assessment:
I will obtain her prior records. We discussed the need for diagnostic colonoscopy with biopsies to evaluate for inflammatory bowel disease versus microscopic colitis versus other etiologies. She feels certain based on her multiple recent health issues that she cannot tolerate this. It is reasonable to do a limited treatment course with budesonide as if she responds rapidly and we can wean this it supports a diagnosis of microscopic colitis over inflammatory bowel disease. At that point we could transition to cholestyramine or colesevelam if necessary. We did discuss that if she does not rapidly improve with treatment she may require a colonoscopy and we would need to schedule this at the hospital.

Monitor clinical course and call with any problems or worsening symptoms in the interim.
Follow-up with PCP for elevated blood pressure reading*

Chief Complaint:
Change in bowel habits, abdominal pain
History of Present Illness:
Cassie is a very pleasant 35-year-old female who presents for evaluation of change in bowel habits and abdominal pain. She notes constipation since she was a child with subsequent hemorrhoids. She routinely uses MiraLAX or stool softeners as needed. Around 6 months ago she had a change in her stooling to diarrhea. She was having 3-4 loose to watery bowel movements per day. She denies any triggering event or medication change. She also is experiencing abdominal pain. This is present in her lower abdomen bilaterally as well as around her umbilicus. She describes this as cramping and squeezing or throbbing. Her pain is worse after defecation. She is also tender to the touch. She does admit occasional rectal bleeding which she relates to hemorrhoids but she is not having any pain at this time. She notes bloating which is present constantly. When symptoms are severe she has associated nausea denies any vomiting. She denies dysphagia or heartburn. She has not had any weight loss. She recently started ibuprofen which has provided relief for her abdominal pain. She was not taking this previously. She has not had any workup for her symptoms. She denies any known GI family history.

Chief Complaint:
worsening chest pain with swallowing
History of Present Illness:
Kathlyn Williams is a 65F patient with a history of H. pylori infection, a-Fib (on Eliquis), CHF, SVT, HTN, HLD, obesity, depression, anxiety, OSA, and former smoker who presents to Gastroenterology clinic as a new patient for evaluation of chest pain that started in August 2025. She initially experienced chest pain following physical therapy and eating a salad, which worsened with swallowing and drinking water. The onset of symptoms coincided with increasing Mounjaro 2.5 to 5 mg. Due to the severity of her symptoms, Kathlyn visited the emergency department on August 11th. The ER confirmed her heart was fine and diagnosed her with inflammation in her chest wall, possibly from exercise, and suspected GERD. She was prescribed omeprazole, and the pain improved with medication and time.
She denies feeling any burning or acid reflux (as she had GERD in the past), describing it as just chest pain. While Kathlyn no longer experiences active heartburn, she recalls significant burping when the chest pain occurred. She also had difficulty swallowing water, which caused pain lower in her chest. She denies nausea or vomiting. Kathlyn reports occasional abdominal pain and inconsistent bowel movements. She mentions experiencing urgency and changes in bowel movements after a steroid shot for stenosis in her back and neck. She denies any blood in her stools. She generally have regular bowel movements with prunes and smooth-tea.
Lab work from 8/14/2025 ED visit notable for creatinine 0.6, sodium 138, potassium 3.6, calcium 10.5, T protein 8.4, albumin 4.2, lipase 15, T. bili 0.4, ALP 75, ALT 17, AST 15, troponin normal, WBC 10.2, hemoglobin 14.9, hematocrit 45.2, PLT 279, normal chest x-ray. She report having a recent abdominal ultrasound ordered by her PCP that was unremarkable other than some gallstones.

Kathlyn Williams is a 65F patient with a history of H. pylori infection, a-Fib (on Eliquis), CHF, SVT, HTN, HLD, obesity, depression, anxiety, OSA, and former smoker who presents to Gastroenterology clinic as a new patient for evaluation of atypical chest pain with dysphagia that started in August 2025.
1. Chest pain with swallowing - Onset August, exacerbated by swallowing and drinking water. Hx of GERD but denies feeling similar. Differential includes atypical GERD, esophageal spasm, anxiety attacks, costochondritis, musculoskeletal pain, cardiac chest pain, reflux esophagitis, peptic stricture, H. pylori infection, peptic ulcer disease, medication-induced GERD, etc.
- Continue omeprazole daily until procedure.
- Schedule diagnostic EGD with biopsies to evaluate esophagus, stomach, and small intestine.
- Biopsy during endoscopy.
- Obtain clearance from cardiologist; of note, patient is on Eliquis.
Follow-Up
- Gastroenterology clinic in 4 months.

Chief Complaint:
GERD, colon cancer screening
History of Present Illness:
Gail Jones is a 75 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit, for complaint of GERD and colon cancer screening. She is scheduled for an EGD and colonoscopy on 9/16/25. She notes that she has been anemic recently. Has been referred to hematology.  She has history of B12 deficiency and has been on monthly injections. Labs in July showed RBC 3.17, Hgb 10.5, HCT 32.3, MCV 101.9, MCH 33.1, plt 209, RDW 12.0. Her B12 and folate levels were normal, and iron panel was normal. She has some mild reflux symptoms. She is taking pantoprazole as needed now, and this works well. She used to take it daily, but has lost about 80 pounds with Mounjaro, and her reflux got significantly less. Has been on Mounjaro for about 2 years.  Has distant hx of lap band with erosion and removal of band, with gastric sleeve done. There is also history o f H. pylori, which was treated, does not recall when. Her last colonoscopy was 10 years ago with Dr. Vadva and it was normal, per patient. She denies constipation, diarrhea, bloody or black stool. There is no family history of colon polyps or colon cancer.
CT 8/22/25 showed prior gastric bariatric surgery, moderate right hydronephrosis with a 12 x 7 mm obstructing calculus in the right ureter, small bilateral renal cysts, left colonic diverticula, mild fat-containing umbilical hernia, 5 cm left adnexal cyst, possibly ovarian in origin, mild bladder wall thickening which may be incomplete distention, although cystitis is not excluded. Per patient, she has been having recurrent UTI and has right back pain. She reports that she was unaware of the kidney stone, but has been referred to "several" doctors, but does not recall any but the hematologist.

Chief Complaint:
Procedure Follow Up
History of Present Illness:
Beth Cameron is a 62 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit for ongoing GI symptoms. Notes chronic constipation. Reports she has been treated twice for SIBO w doxycycline. She reports it helped the first go round but not as much the second time. Has been to the ER in 2021 for bowel impaction and her constipation was worsening which prompted her initial GI with Kelsey Seybold. Has tried low FODMAP in the past. Last colon in 2022 with polyps. She was recommended to try pelvic floor therapy by previous GI. Bowels fluctuate from constipation to diarrhea. Having incomplete evacuation of bowels and ends up with fecal leakage. Has to use imodium often when she is traveling. Excessive gas and melena on occasion. Notes night time reflux and using pepcid AC prn which helps. Low gluten diet helps her symptoms. Had negative celiac panel. On amitrytilline for sleep. Has not tried xifaxin. Uses lubiprostone BID for constipation. CCY in 2020. Bladder suspension surgery many years ago. Uses miralax daily and having BMs but still inconsistent bowels. No blood thinners. No pacemaker or defibrillator.
9/11/25: Here for procedure follow up. Reports she felt great after the colonoscopy and lost 6 days. It took her 4 days after the colonoscopy to have a BM. Still dealing w incomplete emptying, constipation alternating w diarrhea, and bloating. Reflux is manageable and not daily. Trying to eat light dinner which helps w reflux.
Colonoscopy, 8/27/2025, Mild diverticulosis of the Left colon, 1 polyp (3 mm to 4 mm) in the sigmoid colon. (Polypectomy), Several polyps (3 mm to 4 mm) in the rectum. Path neg for celiac, hpylori, candida. Random colon bx neg. Benign colon polyps.

Chief Complaint:
reflux and bloating
History of Present Illness:
Ms. Enriquez is a 70-year-old Spanish-speaking only female accompanied by her daughter. She is seen today due to chronic acid reflux and dysphagia. She states she has had reflux her entire life and has been on multiple medications, all without relief. She did have hiatal hernia repair by fundoplication years ago. She was told this would fix her reflux but she continues to have it. She avoids all foods that typically cause acid reflux. She sleeps with her head of bed elevated. She does usually eat a small snack about an hour before going to bed. She feels reflux throughout the day but especially at night. She states she has a burning sensation that goes all the way up to her nose. She is also complaining of abdominal bloating after eating. She denies any nausea or vomiting. She does report solid food dysphagia but cannot identify any specific foods. She did an EGD in 2023 that showed gastroesophageal flap valve classified as Hill grade 1, a partial fundoplication was found, benign-appearing esophageal stenosis, but was otherwise normal.
She does report frequent bowel movements and cramping in the morning but typically resolves throughout the day. She denies any blood in her stool. Colonoscopy in April of this year was normal.

Chief Complaint:
hospital follow up (TRHS)
History of Present Illness:
Janet Alcorn is a 77 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last visit 12/2024. She was doing very well until 8/26/2025 when developed acute onset of severe generalized abdominal pain and nausea. Due to symptoms she presented to TRHS ER with CT imaging with partial small bowel obstruction, narrowing of mid transverse colon, diverticulosis, chole, and hysterectomy -reviewed with patient. She was made NPO and an NG tube was put in (x 4 attempts) and then after that she developed melena which was felt to possibly be related to trauma. She had also started cilostazol the day of ER visit and has been on long term eliquis so both of these were held (and continue to be on hold) and she also required blood transfusion x 2. She was hospitalized x 1 week and was discharged about 1 week ago with resolution of melena, nausea, and abdominal pain and improvement of labs. She was told to get further instructions regarding restarting her blood thinners from GI; she did restart baby aspirin last Friday. She has not had repeat labs since discharge. Denies dysphagia, vomiting. She is currently having a bowel movement every 3 days, last BM was yesterday. She does not feel constipated and denies diarrhea. Denies hematochezia, recurrence of melena, or fever. Denies unexplained weight loss and reports she has a good appetite and is not following any specific diet restrictions right now. She remains on pantoprazole due to long term GERD hx but is now on BID dosing since hospitalization. History of right hemicolectomy in 2017 due to diverticulitis. Family history of colon cancer with brother and sister. Family history of stomach cancer with mom. Last EGD 4/2023, Colonoscopy 5/2022. Prior CTs 2023 and 2019. History of Thalassemia diagnosed years ago with hematology but has not required following them for many years.  Denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or fatigue. Denies lung disease. Hx of CKD, stage 3, which has been stable. Denies smoking or alcohol use. History of DM which is under control with diet/lifestyle modifications.

nausea, feels like something stuck in her throat
History of Present Illness:
Lori Naquin is a 47 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. She started with nausea after eating a chicken wrap 2 weeks ago. This followed with an episode of vomiting which has not recurred but her nausea persists. She saw her PCP and had labs. CBC, CMP, lipase were normal-reviewed on her portal during visit. Gallbladder US showed fatty liver and a gallstone-no records. She is still nauseated and has no appetite. She has been on liquids, jello since she has been sick. She ate mashed potatoes last night and did okay. She feels like when she swallows- sensation of food "going around something." She feels like something is stuck when she swallows. She is on a daily PPI. She was on twice daily dose at once point but decreased back down to once daily. She is taking Carafate as needed with some improvement. She has history of Peptic ulcer disease. She is on low dose aspirin daily. Denies other NSAID use and only takes Tylenol. Her last EGD here was in 2015.
She has noticed mild constipation with her recent diet changes but not taking anything. She had a single episode ofdiarrhea once last week but has returned to normal. Chief Complaint:
Ulcerative colitis, immunosuppression from drug therapy
History of Present Illness:
Mr. Morris is a 44 year old male with ulcerative colitis & SSA colon polyps, here today for follow up to discuss continuation of therapy following trial. Currently on etrasimod.
-  IBD type: left sided UC
-  Yr dx: 24 y/o
-  Recent colonoscopy: 10/21/2024 (Dr. Malakouti) Research scope.  Loss of vascularity and scar tissue in the rectum and sigmoid colon. 8mm SSA colon polyp. No colon bx path given research scope
-  Current therapy: Velsipity daily
-  Smoking- vapes nicotine
-  EIMs- none currently
-  complications/surgeries: none
Briefly, diagnosed at age 24 with UC. Established with Dr. Ramos in 03/2028 with bloody mucous diarrhea following back surgery. Scope showed active left sided UC and did not respond to mesalamine. Enrolled into Arena trial in 06/2020.
Currently on Velsipity daily, no missed doses.
Overall doing well. States had a rough morning this weekend following breakfast with eggs and a lot of seasoning. Reports had non-bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. States this is rare though and typically has a routine. Wakes up at 4am and drinks 2 cups of coffee and has a BM but states it takes 45 minutes. Passes stool but can be followed by abdominal pain and another stool. Then he is done for day. No bleeding, nocturnal stools, or mucous.
Continues to vape nicotine.
EIMs- reports right elbow tendonitis treated with doxycycline through PCP.
Denies vaccines. Thinks he will get the flu vaccine through work this year.
No skin cancer screening completed.
Eye exam completed with the trial within the year.
Comes off the trial next month after scope.

Chief Complaint:
Annual follow up for IBD colitis
History of Present Illness:
PRIOR HX:
This is a 17-year-old young gentleman currently doing very well who has a history of severe abdominal symptoms in the past. Around the year 2011 he became ill and developed abdominal pain with diarrhea, weight loss that then spiraled into significant anxiety and depression. He underwent extensive workups and was ultimately told he had pancreatic insufficiency. It sounds like it is a pancreatic stimulation test and perhaps a stool test for fecal fat. He was placed on Creon but continued to struggle with abdominal symptoms over the years and had a pediatric psychiatrist and psychologist. He noted negative genetic testing for hereditary pancreatitis. His current pediatric GI doctor has questioned a diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency. There was an attempt to stop pancreatic enzymes about 5-6 years ago. At that time he did well for a few months then developed greasy stools and recurrent abdominal symptoms so restart medication.
Over the past 2 years he has done very well and has actually no issues. He is no longer seeing a psychiatrist and has one last visit with a psychologist he's done with that as well. He is very active in school and seems well adjusted.
From my standpoint is not entirely clear that he truly has pancreatic insufficiency. Certainly irritable bowels a much more common diagnosis then pancreatic insufficiency of unknown etiology.
Today he and his mother and I discussed considering at some point a trial of stopping Creon and see how he does. If we were to do this we probably do this over the summer in a time when he does not have significant obligations or stresses. If we do this I would then probably we'll check a stool for fecal elastase as well as a 48 hour stool collection for fecal fat perhaps 1 month after stopping enzymes.
He will call me should he wish to try this at some point. In the meantime is very reasonable to continue Creon. In the past he has been severely debilitated from his symptoms and now is doing very well so I do not feel the need to rush into changing anything
3/12/2019 (MB) - Jacob Decker is a 18 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Feeling really well. Still taking creon before meals but would like to discuss stopping medication. Taking miralax and one tablet of Dulcolax daily. BMs are mainly X1 BM per day but may vary. If having increasing constipation he increases miralax. No BRBPR or melena. No abd pain. Weight stable. In senior year. Plans to take AP calculus exam May 2019. Wil attend Kansas State in the fall to study mechanical engineering.
5/8/2019 (MB) - Jacob Decker is a 18 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Having X1 BM/Day without BRBPR or melena. Taking 5 caps of creon before meals and 2 with snack. Had increasing sx of constipation last weekend; used a "miralax clean out" as previously instructed by Peds GI. Weight stable. AP calculus exam is one week from today followed by senior trip to Disney World and graduation.
Pleasant 18 y/o male presents for f/u. Finishing senior year in the next two weeks. Will decrease creon dose over one week after graduation. Will obtain fecal elastase and 48 hour stool collection for fecal fat one month after stopping creon. Recommended keeping record of number of stools per day and consistency.
labs 6/19 - elastase low at 111, fecal fat 24 hour collect 5.6 grams/24 hour
given how well he has done on creon and given these labs which show markedly depressed fecal elastase and quantitative fat that is approaching 7g/24 hours, I would recommend that he restart and remain on creon
creon lipase 36,000 USP units - 2 pills with meals, 1 with snacks should be adequate...
OFFICE f/u 7.30.19 -doing well. came off creon for 1 month and then had above testing - off creon he noted more frequent bm. no real cramping. mom notes in 2013 fecal elastase 48 and may 2013 it was 11 and 1/12 - 23. all of this is from his mom however.........
on ezymes for past week and was off for 5 weeks.
3/11/2020 (MB) - Jacob Decker is a 19 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Engineering Major at Kansas State and lives in dorm. Eats a consistent diet while at school. Some weight gain. Home on Spring Break. Has been taking creon most days but after a change in his schedule has not been as consistent (takes at dinner but will miss dose at lunch). No steatorrhea or diarrhea. No change in BHs.
Started noticing BRB on stool early January with most BMs. No rectal pain. Has intermittent constipation for which he uses miralax. BRBPR Sx slowly increasing over last month with dramatic increase 3/6/2020. Has been feeling need to have a BM and having BRB filling the toilet. He had taken advil for back pain before driving home. No other NSAIDs. Started seeing BRB on TP, on stool and filling toilet. No rectal pain.
Has had occasional upper abd bloating but cannot relate to food triggers. No N/V, fever or chills.
Has hx of anal fissures.
No heart palpitations, dizziness upon standing or DOE.
Pleasant 19 y/o male with hx of IBS and EPI presents for evaluation of BRBPR onset early 1/2020 with increase in sx 3/6/2020.
Rectal exam with small fissure anteriorly and internal hemorrhoids with BRB.
Pt to continue creon. Will titrate miralax to a soft BM.
Will obtain CBC to assess for anemia.
For hemorrhoids recommend sitz baths and hydrocortisone suppository. Emphasized the importance of preventing constipation.

Acute and chronic pancreatitis have been described in adults and children with inflammatory bowel disease (either Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis) and may precede the diagnosis of the bowel disease [68,69]. A common feature of these reports is the presence of colonic disease. In the setting of these diseases, the pathogenesis of the pancreatitis probably is multifactorial, including side effects of medications, but an autoimmune mechanism is also possible.
In patients with UC, factors independently associated with AIP included proctitis (odds ratio [OR], 2.9; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.3-6.3; P =.007) and colectomy (OR, 7.1; 95% CI, 2.5-20; P =.0003). In patients with CD, AIP was significantly associated with fewer perianal lesions (OR, 0.16; 95% CI, 0.03-0.77; P =.023), non-stricturing non-penetrating CD (OR, 6.7; 95% CI, 1.25-33.3; P =.0029), and higher rate of colectomy (OR, 27.8; 95% CI, 3.6-217; P =.0029).
In a multicenter retrospective analysis of patients with AIP and IBD, followed for an average of 5.7Â±4.9 years, we found most to have type 2 AIP. Two-thirds of patients have UC, often with proctitis. One-third of patients have CD, often with inflammatory features. Patients with IBD and AIP have higher rates of colectomy than patients with just IBD
telehealth visit 6.11.20
Inflammatory bowel disease: Recent colonoscopy showed moderate proctitis and mild colitis involving the right colon. The ileum was normal. The distribution was patchy consistent with Crohn's. At that time he was having more urgency and bleeding. Currently the bleeding is gone. He has no urgency. He has a bowel movement daily or every few days requiring a laxative. At this time recommended continuing oral mesalamine and Canasa suppositories. He needs to have another colonoscopy to remove the serrated adenoma that was biopsied but not removed. At the time of follow-up colonoscopy to look for mucosal improvement. If indeed there has been significant improvement particularly in the rectum we can then try to taper down and perhaps off the Canasa. He needs to have blood work which we discussed and he will do so for me. We discussed inflammatory bowel great detail and the fact that he may need more aggressive medication future.
Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency: Etiology has been unknown but there are case reports of chronic pancreatitis developing in patients years before the diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease. He has never had acute pancreatitis and as such classic autoimmune pancreatitis as an etiology for his chronic pancreatitis I think would be unlikely. However there may certainly be a link between his inflammatory bowel disease and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency. He does well on Creon. This will be continued for now.
Anxiety: He's been having significant anxiety recently has a history of this. We will start Paxil and I've given him the name of a psychologist, Chris bedard. I've also recommended he establish care with an adult internist to manage this moving forward. I provided him with this, the number of days. I did discuss with him and his family that at times SSRIs can actually exacerbate anxiety and this happens he stop medication call me. I've also has a call in about 4 weeks to let me know how the medication is working.
Personal history of colon polyps: There is a serrated adenoma that was biopsied but not removed during last colonoscopy as I thought it was likely inflammatory fold. It was however tattooed. We will now proceed with colonoscopy and removed this polyp.

Chief Complaint:
Follow up
History of Present Illness:
This is a routine follow-up visit for Jennie, who was last seen in March 2025. The follow-up is primarily for elevated liver enzymes. There is a history of four hospitalizations last year since September, with the most recent admission in February 2025 to UTMB hospital for vomiting. This episode was associated with elevated liver enzymes secondary to isoniazid treatment. The isoniazid was initiated for a positive tuberculosis test, which was required before starting Tremfya for psoriatic arthritis. The isoniazid was discontinued in February 2025, and a course of rifampin was completed in June 2025. She are currently still on Tremfya, administered by Dr. Wong, for psoriatic arthritis, which is reported to be slightly helpful. She also have a history of lupus, diagnosed in 1974, and are on a tapering dose of prednisone, currently at 5 mg daily. A history of fatty liver disease is also noted. There is a report of a liver biopsy performed approximately 20 years ago in Houston, but the results are unknown. No alcohol use or smoking is reported.
Prior Tests Reviewed:
- Labs from UTMB on 06/05/2025 showed a bilirubin of 1.3 and an AST of 136.
- Review of UTMB chart shows AST levels were significantly elevated in February 2025, around 300 (range 30-40), and have been trending down but remain elevated. It is noted that the AST has been high for years.
- Autoimmune workup from the February 2025 admission at UTMB was reviewed. The liver kidney microsomal antibody and anti-mitochondrial antibody were negative. The smooth muscle antibody was slightly elevated at 48, though the smooth muscle titer was negative (<1:20). Immunoglobulin G was normal at 1300.
3/19/2025 She is here along with her daughter for hospital follow-up after recent admission at UTMB for vomiting and weakness. She was also found to have elevated troponin which was thought to be type II MI in the setting of hypovolemia.
Elevated LFTs were noted during admission. Per daughter, his seemed to start shortly after she was started on rifampin/isoniazid for latent TB. She has TB testing every year by her rheumatologist who is treating her with Tremfya for psoriatic arthritis. She also has lupus which is not currently treated however in the past she has used both Plaquenil and azathioprine.
While in the hospital, she was seen by infectious disease. Given high suspicion for DILI related to isoniazid, they discontinued isoniazid in favor of rifampin monotherapy. LFTs remain elevated as of 3/6/2025. Specifically ALT 163, AST 227, alk phos and total bili are within normal range. Chronic liver workup was completed during hospitalization and was negative except for positive SMA. She has a history of transaminitis which was previously attributed to lupus. Discussed the possibility of underlying AIH which would require liver biopsy for diagnosis. She is on cilostazol which may need to be held 48 hours prior. Discussed potential treatment for autoimmune hepatitis which would be steroids or azathioprine. While she did not have any obvious side effects with azathioprine in the past, she has had 2 episodes of pancreatitis of unclear etiology and we would generally avoid using AZA based on that. I will discuss case with GI and rheumatologist if needed to help reach consensus on utility of liver biopsy in her case.
11/4/2024 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using audio only communication since video is unavailable. Appropriate consent was obtained. This is a routine follow-up with patient's daughter also present on the call. We reviewed most recent labs which showed stable anemia at 10.8 with iron panel in the low/normal range. No folate or vitamin B12 deficiencies noted. Appears consistent with recent GI bleed which has since resolved. Patient has been monitoring closely for melena or blood in the stool. Symptoms appear to have resolved after discontinuing Plavix. Currently she is on cilostazol monotherapy since she did not tolerate aspirin in the past. We also reviewed slightly elevated lipase on most recent labs however it has been much higher in the past. No current symptoms of abdominal pain or nausea. Recent CT scan at UTMB was unrevealing for pancreatic abnormalities. Recommend follow-up in 6 months or sooner for new GI concerns.
10/01/2024 She is here for hospital follow up along with daughter who helps give history after recent admission to UTMB due to GI bleeding with melena, fatigue, lightheadedness. She was discharged home a week ago. No bleeding or melena reported. Partial records obtained from patient/family since full records were not available at the time of visit. She required more than 1 blood transfusion and underwent EGD which was overall unrevealing. Patient declined colonoscopy given historically challenging procedure due to long loopy colon. Plavix was discontinued prior to arrival in favor of aspirin monotherapy. she had been taking Plavix for stroke that occurred in 2020. Today she is feeling well with no new complaints. no repeat imaging recommended since this was just completed at outside hospital. I will obtain the records and important to her chart for review. We have mutually agreed to defer colonoscopy given age, bleeding resolution, and technically challenging procedure. Recommend repeat labs to include iron panel and lipase as it was elevated last year. She denies any recent abdominal pain.
08/14/2023 This is a follow up appointment. Labs in 08/23 with Cr 1.21, AST 64, lipase 567, IgG4 normal. Patient reports that abdominal pain has improved since last visit. She notes that it seems to be worse after eating certain foods like ice cream and nuts, which she has since cut out from her diet. She is having daily soft BMs with Colace. Denies nausea, vomiting, visible rectal bleeding. Low suspicion for autoimmune pancreatitis at this point with unrevealing CT this year and IgG4 normal. Elevated lipase could be secondary to CKD. Plan to follow up in 6 months, will plan on repeating lipase at that time.
6/27/2023 Patient is here for follow up. Patient is still complaining of epigastric pain that is intermittent, fleeting, and worse with certain movements. Not impacted by eating or defecation. She sometimes takes Tylenol for the pain with some relief. Her BMs are regular with Colace daily. Denies nausea, vomiting, dysphagia, weight loss. She had a CT a/p 6/21 which showed colitis and fatty liver, no masses or inflammation of pancreas. She followed up with rheumatologist last month, who only manages IgG4 related autoimmune pancreatitis. IgG 4 ordered last visit but was not completed. Epigastric pain possible autoimmune pancreatitis vs. chronic constipation and loopy colon. Repeat labs and follow up in 6 weeks.
03/27/2023 She is here for follow-up along with her daughter. Since last visit her diarrhea appears to have resolved. She takes Colace for her suspected overflow diarrhea and notes normal bowel movements at this time. She has stopped taking probiotics. She continues to complain of intermittent epigastric discomfort after eating. She was noted to have elevated lipase on routine blood tests in December along with elevated inflammation markers and liver function tests concerning for possible autoimmune process. An ultrasound was ordered by her primary care physician which showed prominent pancreatic and common bile duct. A CT was ordered but she is still pending insurance approval. We did discuss possibility of autoimmune pancreatitis given her history of psoriatic arthritis as well as lupus. An IgG subclass 4 was ordered but she did not do this lab and she is willing to do this now.
12/14/2022 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using audio only communication since video is unavailable. Appropriate consent was obtained. This is a routine follow-up after 1 month with patient's daughter also present on the call. She reports ongoing weight loss and new diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis as well as possible pancreatitis due to elevated pancreatic enzymes checked by her rheumatologist. Labs will be obtained for review and further counseling. She does have a history of what sounds like idiopathic pancreatitis, 2 episodes in the past. Will consider IgG subclass 4 to rule out autoimmune pancreatitis if not done previously. Of note she had a very recent CT scan with contrast which did not show any pancreatic abnormality. She also had stool tests including fecal elastase which were within normal limits. Her bowel movements are a little bit better since our last visit and she is not using MiraLAX since it upset her stomach. Advised trial of Colace instead.
11/14/2022 She is here along with her daughter after 2 weeks. In the meantime we have repeated her C. difficile stool test which was negative. She also had a urinalysis which was negative for any infection. She still has minimal low-grade fever which seems attributable to her lupus at this point. No GI contraindication to lupus treatment as appropriate per her rheumatologist. She still has vague lower abdominal pain and diarrhea about 4-8 times per day. Recent CT scan showed increased stool burden and she does have altered anatomy with severe redundancy in sigmoid colon on prior colonoscopy. We discussed the high likelihood of overflow diarrhea and C. difficile carrier status rather than true infection. Discussed possibility of referral to colorectal surgery to discuss possibility of diverting colostomy however she is very hesitant. Attending gastroenterologist also present for visit today.
11/01/2022 She is here along with her daughter. She continues to complain of intermittent fevers up to 101. Also continues to have diarrhea. She went to the emergency room few weeks ago with similar complaints and had testing including labs which were overall normal. CT scan showed increased stool burden but otherwise no active signs of infection. She remains on vancomycin given recent history of C. difficile toxin positive gene test on 9/23/2022 and currently on a tapered treatment. She also has lupus and currently going through a flareup with pain in both her hands which is where typically her lupus effects. Her rheumatologist would like to switch to stronger medication but given ongoing fever they are holding off on further immunosuppression. I have recommended expanding infectious disease work-up and if negative will consider aggressive treatment for lupus which can be discussed with her rheumatologist. Given presence of solid stool on CT this is less likely a infectious disease as a cause for diarrhea and more likely overflow diarrhea from constipation.
10/20/2022 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using audio only communication since video is unavailable. Appropriate consent was obtained. This is a 2-day follow-up. In the interim she went to the ER and had Memorial Hermann Southeast related and was assessed with labs and CT and later discharged home. Labs did not reveal any leukocytosis and she was afebrile at the time of presentation. CT scan did not show any colitis and in fact showed moderate stool burden. Patient continues to have abdominal pain and frequent diarrhea. Repeat stool testing was deferred for now in favor for longer duration of vancomycin. We also discussed weaning her off of PPI to decrease risk for future C. difficile recurrence. Patient will use H2 blockers instead in the meantime. Mild macrocytic anemia noted, this will need to be rechecked in the future. Continues to deny any bleeding.
10/18/2022 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using audio only communication since video is unavailable. Appropriate consent was obtained. This is a routine follow-up after 1 month. Since then she was diagnosed with C. difficile on stool test, fecal calprotectin was also elevated in the 600 range. Patient was started on extended course of vancomycin 4 times daily and has about a week left of the medication. She has not contacted office to discuss symptoms however she reports persistent diarrhea about 10+ episodes per day with associated fever up to 102 earlier this morning. She also has abdominal distention and pain which is worse on the right lower quadrant. She is having a hard time maintaining her hydration. She denies any rectal bleeding. She tells me she is supposed to start on a new infusion (Saphnelo) for her lupus later this week which I have advised against given ongoing infection. Given lack of improvement on worsening symptoms including abdominal pain and distention with fever I recommended ER evaluation today for stat labs and CT scan, possible admission for inpatient management if appropriate. Patient agrees. Total time spent was 30 minutes
09/07/2022 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using audio only communication since video is unavailable. We discussed procedure findings in detail including mild gastritis and small hiatal hernia, biopsies are negative for H. pylori. Patient reports acid reflux symptoms which are moderately controlled with pantoprazole daily. Colonoscopy was incomplete due to severe redundancy in sigmoid colon. She had a barium enema later that day which did not reveal any colonic lesion. Most recent labs reviewed and showed mild anemia with hemoglobin of 10.8 and no evidence of iron deficiency. Her main complaint is worsening diarrhea ever since her colonoscopy/barium enema. She also has abdominal cramping which she is treating with dicyclomine. She denies any rectal bleeding. She does have underlying IBS however current symptoms are more frequent and watery. Recommended comprehensive stool testing which she is agreeable to. Of note she does have a history of C. difficile and took a Z-Pak about a month ago for upper respiratory infection.
5/31/2022 She is here for follow-up along with her daughter. She has been sent back by her PCP and complains of anemia. She was noted to have a hemoglobin of around 11.7 in April of this year, 11 4 weeks ago and 10.72 weeks ago. She complains of being tired all the time. Denies any specific bleeding. She is on Plavix given history of 4 strokes previously approximately 2 years ago. Last colonoscopy was in 2017 which was negative and last EGD was in 2015 which was negative at that time. She does have history of steatosis with grade 1 and stage I fibrosis on liver biopsy in 2015. I recommended that she consult with her neurologist here for ongoing antiplatelet therapy is warranted in light of her progressive anemia and if it would be appropriate to switch her to an enteric-coated 81 mg aspirin. We will order labs to further investigate anemia, check for nutritional disorders and if it is persistent consideration for EGD and colonoscopy pending cardiac clearance. Risks and benefits of procedure discussed in detail.

1/19/2022 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using bidirectional synchronous video communication tool. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a routine follow-up after 2 months. Patient is doing well with no new GI complaints. We reviewed most recent ultrasound which showed a prior cholecystectomy and mild fatty liver. No acute changes noted. She denies any abdominal pain. She still has mild intermittent diarrhea which she equates to IBS-D. No recent symptoms similar to prior C. difficile infection. She had labs last month with outside physician which we will request records for. Recommend routine follow-up in 6 months or sooner if she has any worsening symptoms or abnormal labs
11/30/2021 She is here along with her care provider. She notes significant improvement in diarrhea after extending the course of oral vancomycin. I did warn her against taking antibiotics unless it is absolutely necessary due to history of C. difficile infection. I recommended that she stay on probiotics. She does have history of irritable bowel syndrome with the diarrhea has intermittent cramps, was previously taking Librax. Given the potential side effects of excess sedation and her advanced age I recommended consider dicyclomine. Recently she was noted to have elevated liver function tests with routine labs with her rheumatologist for lupus with ALT of 75 and AST of 185. She was previously taking Imuran 3 times a day and it has been reduced to twice a day. She is status post cholecystectomy. Denies any nausea vomiting or right upper quadrant pain but does have generalized abdominal discomfort. I recommended that we get a baseline ultrasound of the liver given elevated liver function test. I did discuss possibility that elevated liver tests could also be from lupus itself and not necessarily a drug reaction.
11/10/2021 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using audio only communication since video is unavailable. Appropriate consent was obtained. This is a routine follow-up after 2 weeks. In that timeframe patient was diagnosed with C. difficile colitis and started on oral vancomycin. Ciprofloxacin and metronidazole were discontinued upon stool test findings. She also had a CT scan of abdomen pelvis which shows colonic diverticulosis with surrounding inflammation suggestive of diverticulitis abutting vaginal cuff and possible cystitis. Patient has had recent urinalysis and vaginal exam which were negative. Her abdominal pain has almost completely resolved however she is still having frequent diarrhea without bleeding or fever. Recommend continue vancomycin as prescribed and follow-up as scheduled in 2 weeks. She will contact office if she has any new or worsening symptoms in the meantime. Total time spent was 20 minutes.
10/25/2021 Patient is here with her daughter for initial visit. She was previously seen by one of our partners in 2017. Patient reports chronic diarrhea for most of her life which has worsened in the past 1 year. She is currently having frequent very loose stools about 8/day. She also reports some diffuse abdominal pain which is worse in lower abdomen. She was recently treated with an unknown antibiotic for urinary tract infection however diarrhea symptoms predated this antibiotic. She has some intermittent low-grade fevers which they attribute to her history of lupus. She was hospitalized for a stroke in May 2020 and has been on Plavix since that time. She has multiple associated comorbidities including CHF and COPD and will require clearance if any endoscopic evaluation is planned. Today we reviewed colonoscopy report from 2017 which was negative except for simoid diverticulosis, no biopsies obtained. On exam she does have some lower abdominal tenderness worse in suprapubic area. I recommend treatment with Cipro and Flagyl as well as comprehensive stool test to rule out other infectious pathogens and check fecal calprotectin. She will also complete a CT scan of abdomen pelvis prior to follow-up visit. We could consider colonoscopy in the future however prefer to manage with noninvasive methods if possible given her comorbidities.
3/7/2017 JENNIE ONEAL is seen today for a follow-up visit. Patient reports that trial of metform for NAFLD failed due to severe diarrhea and fecal incontinence. We agreed to stop it. We reviewed ways to decrease calorie intake in the setting of NAFLD and otherwise negative work up of chronic liver disease. We also reviewed her colonoscopy, repeat in 10 years recommended.
She has intermittent diarrhea and relies on loperamide PRN. it would be ok to continue with that approach.
2/6/2017 - JENNIE ONEAL is seen today for a follow-up visit. Patient is referred for colorectal cancer screening. There is no family history of colorectal neoplasia. Patient denies any hematochezia/ rectal bleeding, change in bowel habit or stool caliber, abdominal pain, nausea, emesis, heartburn, odynophagia, dysphagia, early satiety, weight loss.
Patient also with f/u for NAFLD with early fibrosis. She reports attempts for weight loss have been unsuccessful. No etoh intake. She has a family member with A1-Antitrypsin deficiency, her levels were normal in 2015.
6/23/2015 - JENNIE ONEAL is seen today for a follow-up visit. We reviewed biopsy results. No evidence of autoimmune hepatitis. However she does have G1S1 steatohepatitis on liver biopsy. These findings are consistent with chronic liver disease due to NAFLD. We discussed weight loss techniques as well as need for surveillance in view of early fibrosis noted. She is also intolerant to zantac with severe return of her abdominal symptoms, so I agreed to let her get back to omeprazole.
4/20/2015 - JENNIE ONEAL is seen today for a follow-up visit. We reviewed EGD results which only show mild esophagitis. Because of her concern of side effects of PPI and calcium absorption, we agreed to switch to zantac.
Her labs reviewed a mildly elevated actin antibody as well as positive ANA with a cetromere pattern. I suspect these are related to Scleroderma rather than autoimmune hepatitis. We discussed benefits and risks of liver biopsy to rule out autoimmune hepatitis and agreed to proceed.
3/9/2015 - JENNIE ONEAL is seen for an initial visit today. Patient reports known history of elevation of liver enzymes, presumed to be from fatty liver. No formal work up except for liver enzymes and ultrasounds per patient.
She reports no risk factors for viral hepatitis. No family history of chronic liver disease. She does not drink alcohol excessively. She reports a history of scleroderma with associated reflux symptoms. Most days controlled with over the counter medications.

Chief Complaint: GERD History of Present Illness: The patient is a 41-year-old female presenting with gastroesophageal reflux disease and esophageal stricture. She reports a history of reflux symptoms dating back to her time in graduate school, where she experienced significant swallowing difficulties. The patient underwent two esophageal dilations around 2007-2008, which temporarily resolved her swallowing issues. In the past five years, her symptoms have worsened, with persistent heartburn despite daily use of proton pump inhibitors like Prilosec and Protonix. She experiences nocturnal symptoms severe enough to wake her, accompanied by hoarseness and wheezing, suggestive of possible aspiration. The patient has been managing her symptoms by avoiding trigger foods and using medications like famotidine and Pepcid as needed. Her father had a history of Barrett's esophagus, raising concerns about potential esophageal changes. Debra Ponce is a 64 year old  female patient who is seen at the request of Mary Mcauliffe for a consultation/initial visit.The patient complains of abdominal pain. The pain typically lasts 30 minutes. It usually starts intermittently. Symptom triggers include nothing specific. Alleviating factors include nothing specific.  Symptoms have been non-progressive/stable since onset.  Alarm features noted: none. The patient also reports abdominal bloating/distension and constipation. Symptoms have caused the patient to see primary care physician. Noteworthy prior abdominal interventions include appendectomy (as a child), otherwise denies abdominal surgery. COLONOSCOPY (9 yrs ago, normal to the cecum) has been performed previously to evaluate the patient's symptoms.  Pertinent medical history includes no pertinent history. Chief Complaint:
Constipation
History of Present Illness:
The patient reports experiencing significant constipation throughout this year, which has worsened due to ongoing pain management with medications prescribed by their primary care provider, pain specialist, and neurosurgeon. The patient is scheduled for anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF) at levels C3 through C6 next week. The constipation has required frequent use of over-the-counter laxatives, but the patient is unsure of their baseline bowel movement frequency without these medications, as they typically resort to laxatives after two or three days without a bowel movement. The patient has a history of grade three hemorrhoids, previously not bothersome, but over the past five to six months has developed rectal bleeding associated with constipation. The patient has never undergone a colonoscopy, despite prior recommendations, due to relocation. The patient is currently on medical leave from work.

Chief Complaint:
Constipation, Abd pain
History of Present Illness:
Ruby Farr is a 54 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit for constipation, difficulty with oral intake and weight loss onset June 2025. Patient states that she was in her USOH until she suddenly experienced constipation in which she did not have a bowel movement for a week. She states sx progressed to where she could barely eat and developed significant epigastric pain. She was admitted at Med City North Hills where she underwent inpatient EGD and was told she had ulcers and a hiatal hernia. Was started on Pantoprazole and sucralfate which she has been compliant with. Has also been taking Omeprazole as well. Her epigastric pain has resolved however she is still experiencing constipation despite compliance with Miralax and Benefiber daily. When she goes a week without a bowel movement, she will give herself suppositories and takeDulcolax with relief. She is currently able to tolerate a diet, primarily eating a muffin for breakfast, a chicken or tuna salad for lunch and a small dinner, such as one slice of pizza. She has lost a total of 17 pounds unintentionally since June but attributes this to not being able to eat. She still has intermittent hematochezia, most recently a couple of days ago but states that this is overall improved compared to June when the whole toilet bowl was filled with blood.
She underwent EGD in July 2025 during her admission and per my review of the pictures, it looks like she had Grade B esophagitis and antral gastritis. She does not remember if gastric biopsies were taken. Path report and procedure report not currently available. She also reports she had a CT scan during admission and no obstruction was found. She had colonoscopy in Aug 2025 with note of a very poor bowel prep and incomplete resection of a descending colon polyp in which path revealed tubular adenoma. States she used the Miralax bowel prep and knew that it didn't clean her out completely.
Denies family history of colon cancer. She had been pursuing Cologuards for colon cancer screening prior to her colonoscopy. Ten years ago she had a colonoscopy as she states she had GI problems but does not remember the specifics. Used to drink alcohol socially but has not had any alcohol since June. Denies NSAID use.

sucralfate 1 gram TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH 4 TIMES DAILY ON AN EMPTY STOMACH 1 HOUR BEFORE MEALS AND AT BEDTIME

Assessment:
Ruby Farr is a 54F who presents for sx most likely related to IBS-C however she did have incomplete resection of a tubular adenoma in the descending colon in Aug 2025 in the context of an inadequate bowel prep. Plan is to proceed with diagnostic colonoscopy at this time with five days of a low residue diet followed by Suprep bowel prep. Will plan to perform DRE prior to procedure while patient is awake. For IBS-C, will start Linzess. If not improvement, will consider ARM/BET. Will obtain records from EGD. Pt reports an ulcer was found. Pending review of records, will consider repeat EGD to evaluate for ulcer healing. Continue Pantoprazole for now. Review of labs from 7/18/25 show normal hgb and TSH and normal liver enzymes.

Chief Complaint:
Changes in bowel habits, blood in stool
History of Present Illness:
Patient is 38 year old female with PMHx acid reflux, colitis, endometriosis, IBS presenting to adult gastroenterology clinic to establish care as a new patient.
- Presents for consultation regarding long-standing gastrointestinal symptoms including abdominal discomfort, intermittent constipation and diarrhea, abdominal aches, and nausea. Also reports recent worsening of hemorrhoids with bleeding and is concerned about potential colon cancer.
- Reports that symptoms have become progressively worse with age. In the last three months, symptoms have become particularly severe. The abdominal discomfort is described as being all over but more pronounced in the lower abdomen. Reports that at times her stomach feels like it is "an ice".
- Developed hemorrhoids which have become so severe they bleed with pain. It is sometimes painful to sit. The bleeding is described as frequent, significant in volume, and bright red in color. Sees bright red blood in the toilet bowl. Denies seeing clots or wine-colored/black stool.
- Past medical and surgical history includes a partial colectomy approximately 30 years ago following a car accident. History of C. diff colitis, first diagnosed in 2012, with recurrences in 2013 and 2015. Previous colonoscopies were performed, with the last one in 2012 which identified the C. diff. Previous colonoscopies before 2012 were unremarkable.
- Reports a history of treatment for C. diff, initially with Keflex which was ineffective, followed by a successful course of Vancomycin.
- Social history is significant for extensive travel throughout Europe with her husband for his employment. Denies recent travel to South America, Africa, or Asia. Family history is significant for a grandfather with colon cancer. Parents are well, and there are no siblings with known GI issues.

Diagnoses:
Rectal bleeding (c)
Diarrhea (c)
Constipation
Abdominal pain, epigastric (c,e)
Family history of colon cancer
Acid reflux
History of Clostridioides difficile colitis
Assessment:
1. Abdominal pain and change in bowel habits
- Assessment: The constellation of symptoms including lower abdominal pain, intermittent diarrhea and constipation, and bloating is concerning. The history of partial colectomy, recurrent C. diff infections, and antibiotic use suggests a potential for dysbiosis contributing to her symptoms. Differential diagnoses include IBD (Crohn's, ulcerative colitis), infectious colitis (recurrent C. diff), celiac disease, H. pylori, and functional bowel disorder secondary to dysbiosis or food intolerances.
- Investigations planned:
- Blood work: To be drawn today. Will include serology for celiac disease.
- Stool studies: Kits to be provided today. Will test for a panel of infectious pathogens including C. diff, E. coli, Salmonella, Shigella, as well as parasites. Also for inflammatory markers.
- EGD and Colonoscopy: To be scheduled. Will evaluate the upper GI tract, the remainder of the colon. Biopsies will be taken to rule out IBD, H. pylori, and celiac disease.
- Lifestyle modifications: Discussed the role of food, particularly non-fermentable sugars (FODMAPs) in foods like watermelon, broccoli, cabbage, onions, and garlic, as a potential cause of bloating and spasm if structural and infectious causes are ruled out. The role of stress was also discussed as an amplifier of symptoms.
- Follow-up appointments: A follow-up visit is scheduled for 2-3 weeks after the endoscopic procedures to discuss all results (biopsies, blood work, stool studies) and formulate a definitive management plan together in mutual decision making.
2. Rectal bleeding
- Assessment: The bright red rectal bleeding is likely secondary to internal hemorrhoids, but the possibility of underlying pathology, including malignancy, needs to be excluded, especially given family history of colon cancer and increasing incidence in younger populations.
- Investigations planned: Colonoscopy will be planned for evaluation of above etiologies.
- Medical treatment planned:
- Anusol-HC (hydrocortisone) suppositories prescribed for hemorrhoids, to be used twice daily for 10-14 days. Jessica was counseled to insert a suppository and rest for 20-30 minutes to allow it to dissolve. She will report on its efficacy at the follow-up visit.
- Relevant referrals: If internal hemorrhoids are confirmed on colonoscopy and are refractory to suppositories, a referral will be made to Dr. Cox, colorectal surgeon, for consideration of office-based hemorrhoid banding. Discussed the tiered approach to hemorrhoid treatment: Tier 1 (creams/suppositories), Tier 2 (banding), and Tier 3 (hemorrhoidectomy).
Plan:
EGD/Colonoscopy with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235/45378
Risks and benefits statement: The procedure and its preparation, benefits, alternatives, and limitations were explained to the patient or legal guardian. The risks and potential complications including but not limited to perforation, bleeding, infection, missed lesion, aspiration and other complications of sedation were reviewed. The patient or legal guardian verbalized understanding and wishes to proceed.

Chief Complaint:
right side pain
hiatal hernia
fatty liver
elevated lft's
gerd
History of Present Illness:
In today's new patient visit, 55 year old female with no known history presents for initial consultation to follow up on gastrointestinal symptoms that have been ongoing for over a year. About a year ago, while in Las Vegas, she reported right upper quadrant pain to her primary care provider. This prompted a series of investigations including an abdominal ultrasound, a HIDA scan, and an upper endoscopy.
The investigations from a year ago revealed several findings. The ultrasound demonstrated hepatic steatosis (fatty liver) but no evidence of cholelithiasis. The HIDA scan showed a significantly diminished and negligible gallbladder ejection fraction, noted to be compatible with chronic cholecystitis or severe gallbladder dysmotility (biliary dyskinesia). The upper endoscopy identified a hiatal hernia. At that time, symptoms included heartburn, gastric reflux, and intermittent right upper quadrant pain. She was advised to take Pepcid (famotidine) on an as-needed basis.
Initially, she used famotidine only occasionally. However, over the past several months, her symptoms have worsened. She now reports needing to take famotidine almost daily, regardless of her dietary intake. She describes experiencing reflux and pain even after consuming bland foods like a sandwich, chips, and yogurt. The pain, which was previously predominantly in the right upper quadrant, is now also experienced in the epigastric region. She reports that symptoms, including reflux and heartburn, can be severe enough to awaken her from sleep. She also notes associated bloating and a sensation of abdominal hardness. The famotidine provides some relief, but she is concerned about the increasing frequency of use and the persistence of her symptoms. She still reports intermittent RUQ pain, but it is not as often as her other symptoms. She denies jaundice or unintentional weight loss.
The patient was seen by a different gastroenterologist previously who reportedly did not address the fatty liver finding and stated that the gallbladder issue was not severe enough to warrant intervention, despite the HIDA scan results. She expresses concern about the fatty liver, particularly after a friend's mother recently passed away from complications of cirrhosis that developed from undiagnosed fatty liver. Recent lab work from her primary care provider has shown persistently elevated liver enzymes, specifically the alkaline phosphatase (ALP). She has not had any repeat imaging since the initial workup a year ago.
A review of her recent and past laboratory results was conducted. A lab report from 09/24/2024 showed an ALP of 140. Another from October 2024 showed an ALP of 131 and an elevated ALT. Her most recent labs showed an ALP of 129, with normal AST and ALT. A GGT level was noted to be elevated at 93 on one report. A hepatitis panel was negative. She also has a history of hypothyroidism, and labs from her endocrinologist were reviewed, which also showed a previously elevated ALP. She denies any history of nausea or vomiting. Bowel movements are reported to be normal for the most part, without any bleeding or other lower abdominal pain.
Her previous colonoscopy had a poor prep, but a subsequent Cologuard test was negative in 2024.

Assessment:

- EGD in 2024 showed grade 1 esophagitis, sliding medium hiatal hernia
- Will start pantoprazole 40 mg QD to see if symptoms are controlled with PPI therapy.
2. RUQ pain/elevated ALP/biliary dyskinesia
- Severe biliary dyskinesia diagnosed via HIDA scan approximately one year ago, which showed a negligible gallbladder ejection fraction.
- Persistently elevated ALP on multiple lab draws over the past year, with levels ranging from 129 to 140.
- Experiences intermittent right upper quadrant pain, though this is currently less prominent than her epigastric and heartburn symptoms.
- Will order RUQ US to re-assess for cholestatic processes and biliary obstruction causing elevated ALP
- If symptoms persist despite PPI therapy and RUQ US is unremarkable for causes of her pain, will consider elective cholecystectomy for treatment of biliary dyskinesia
3. Fatty liver
- Dx on ultrasound in 2024
- Will re-assess with ultrasound now
- If seen on ultrasound again, will assess further with a Fibroscan for fibrosis
4. Colon CA screening
- Cologuard negative in 2024
- Due for screening colonoscopy in 2027

Plan:
Copy of records from Waco Gastro (EGD), GES, u/s, etc ( Ascension), colonoscopy (Coriscana, Novarro Regional), and Fairfield Hosp D/c summary last month.
During flares, takes scheduled zofran/ondansetron 4 mg three times a day before eating and change to clear liquids until symptoms improve. Then, target a goal of 6 small frequent low fat meals of less than or around 300 calories each meal.
Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
ondansetron 4 mg Dissolve 1 tablet in mouth every four to six hours as needed
Start scheduled Miralax 17 g (one cap full) daily with 8 oz water. Titrate to 2 capfuls a day if needed.
Avoid NSAIDs and bowel motility slowing agents.
Follow-up office visit in 3 months

Chief Complaint:
Follow-up for elevated liver enzymes after hospital admission for right upper quadrant pain.
History of Present Illness:
Adriana Sanchez is a 32 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Admitted to Memorial Hermann Southeast Medical Center with right upper quadrant and epigastric pain. Blood work revealed elevated liver enzymes. Cholecystectomy performed in the past (July 2025). Suspected choledocholithiasis. MRCP was negative for stone but showed a dilated common bile duct, more than expected post-cholecystectomy. Pancreas was normal. Discharged on 08/15/2025 with instructions for follow-up. Last LFTs on 08/15/2025: total bilirubin 0.58, alkaline phosphatase 189, AST 397, ALT 421. MRI also showed fatty liver. Reports current pain has resolved. Also reports long-standing history of heartburn and stomach burning, particularly after eating spicy food. Describes the sensation as a scratch. Has not used any medication for this. Recently, since the cholecystectomy in July 2025, has experienced intermittent dysphagia with solid foods, not liquids. Bowel habits are erratic, alternating between constipation and diarrhea. Denies lower abdominal cramping, blood, or mucus in stool. Does not smoke or drink alcohol. Does not take over-the-counter pain medications.
