Fatty liver, non-alcoholic
Liver enzymes abnormal
IBS (irritable bowel syndrome)
Status post cholecystectomy
Assessment:
Seen for follow-up after recent hospitalization for right upper quadrant pain and elevated liver enzymes. The pain has resolved. The working theory was a passed common bile duct stone given the negative MRCP but dilated duct. There are three primary issues to address: 1) Elevated liver enzymes and fatty liver, 2) GERD-like symptoms with new-onset dysphagia, and 3) Irregular bowel habits consistent with IBS.
PLAN:
1. Elevated Liver Enzymes and Fatty Liver [K76.0]
- Repeat liver function tests to check if enzymes have normalized.
- If LFTs remain elevated, will proceed with further blood work to rule out chronic liver disease.
- To investigate the degree of scarring from fatty liver, a FibroScan is ordered. This will be done in Webster.
- Will refer to a clinical trial for fatty liver. Patient counseled that they may be contacted by the trial team.
2. Gastroesophageal Reflux and Dysphagia [K21.9]
- Start pantoprazole 40 mg one tablet daily before breakfast for reflux symptoms.
- Schedule for an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) to evaluate for underlying pathology, including infection or celiac disease.
- Patient counseled on EGD procedure: must be fasting (NPO) on the day of the procedure and must have a driver to take them home.
3. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) [K58.9]
- Recommends over-the-counter Benefiber powder.
- Instructions: one tablespoon of powder mixed in a large glass of water, to be taken every night to help regulate bowel movements.
4. Referral to chronic care management: GERD, Dyspepsia, Fatty Liver, obesity
Plan:
Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
pantoprazole 40 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth once a day 30 min before breakfast
EGD with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235
Risks and benefits statement: The procedure and its preparation, benefits, alternatives, and limitations were explained to the patient or legal guardian. The risks and potential complications including but not limited to perforation, bleeding, infection, missed lesion, aspiration and other complications of sedation were reviewed. The patient or legal guardian verbalized understanding and wishes to proceed.
Fibroscan + RUQ ultrasound
Liver Function Panel (HFP)
Follow-up office visit in 1 month

Assessment:
Assessment and Plan
78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease presenting with dysphagia. The patient has persistent dysphagia to both solids and liquids despite previous EGD with dilation, indicating a need for further intervention.
The presence of a Schatzki's ring was noted in past evaluations, which may contribute to the ongoing symptoms. Given the persistence of symptoms, a repeat EGD with a larger dilator is planned, along with esophageal manometry to assess esophageal function.
1. Dysphagia
The patient will undergo an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with dilation using a larger dilator to address the persistent dysphagia. Esophageal manometry will also be performed to evaluate esophageal motility and function. Reflux precautions were discussed with the patient to manage symptoms.
2. Schatzki's Ring
The presence of a Schatzki's ring has been noted in previous evaluations and contributes to the patient's dysphagia. The planned EGD with dilation aims to alleviate the obstruction caused by the ring.
3. Coronary Artery Disease
The patient's coronary artery disease is stable, and he is currently on Xarelto for anticoagulation. Xarelto will be held for two days prior to the procedure to minimize bleeding risk.
Plan:
EGD with dilation as needed with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43249
Risks and benefits statement: The procedure and its preparation, benefits, alternatives, and limitations were explained to the patient or legal guardian. The risks and potential complications including but not limited to perforation, bleeding, infection, missed lesion, aspiration and other complications of sedation were reviewed. The patient or legal guardian verbalized understanding and wishes to proceed.
High fiber diet (Beyond the Basics), patient education materials generated by EMR
Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil, ibuprofen, Aleve, Naproxen) for 3 days.
Hold Xarelto (rivaroxaban) for 2 days prior to planned procedure

Assessment:
The natural history, pathophysiology and treatment of SIBO was reviewed with the patient. Patient completed his course of Xifaxan 3 days ago. We discussed giving it an additional 2 weeks to see if it takes more effect. If he continues with his symptoms after 2 weeks, he will take a course of Augmentin for second-line treatment. A low-carb diet was recommended to prevent symptom recurrence. Patient agrees with the plan.
The natural history, pathophysiology and treatment of fatty liver was reviewed with the patient. Weight loss, diet, exercise, avoidance of alcohol and tobacco as well as aggressive management of cardiovascular risk factors were reinforced. I will check an MRI liver elastography for further evaluation of hepatic fibrosis. He will follow-up with me in 1 month to review results. We reviewed his abdominal ultrasound and discussed that his gallbladder looked normal. I will check LFTs for further evaluation.

Kyoko Dillman  is a 77 year old   female  who is seen today for a follow-up visit. PMHx: Hepatitis B stage II, osteopenia, sleep apnea, former smoker, chronic leukopenia, multiple family member with hepatitis B and brother with cirrhosis, LPR.
The patient is here for follow-up after recent labs and ultrasound. She has a history of chronic hepatitis B and is currently maintained on daily Entecavir. Since her last visit, she was evaluated by ENT and diagnosed with laryngopharyngeal reflux. Referred for voice therapy, but this did not provide additional benefit. Responding well to famotidine 40 mg daily, with resolution of cough and hoarseness of voice. Alcohol use only on special occasions. The patient again declined colonoscopy and prefers to continue with Cologuard screening, which was completed last year and was negative.
Her creatinine continues to rise on recent labs. She has seen nephrology follow-up many years ago but has not seen nephrology recently.

abnormal LFT's

Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain
History of Present Illness:
58-year-old female presents for telemedicine follow up of GERD, dysphagia, diverticulitis and constipation.
She is taking Pantoprazole 40 mg once daily. Dysphagia is improved. With missed doses she will having reflux indigestion symptoms. She also notes episodes of severe epigastric pain that occur approximately once a week and last 2-20 minutes. She has not been able to identify triggers. The last episode occurred Sunday night; she was awakened from her sleep. She notes associated nausea. Pain does not improve after a BM. Denies vomiting, weight loss.
Denies any lower abdominal pain. She takes Linzess intermittently. She averages 1-2 BMs daily without straining, fully empties. She notes intermittent loose stools. Denies hematochezia, melena, rectal bleeding.
She is on Wegovy and has lost approximately 6 lb.
She is also on clopidogrel for history of TIA; last in 3/2025.
Available records reviewed and include:
3/18/2019: Colonoscopy: Internal hemorrhoids.
2/4/25: Hb 13, plts 333.
2/4/25: CTA abdomen/pelvis: Mild thickening of colon at hepatic flexure with scattered colonic diverticula. 2.5cm hemangioma in posterior right lobe of liver. No evidence of GI bleed.
3/8/25: T bili 0.7, AST 23, ALT 26, alk phos 181. LDL 112. TSH 1.58. INR 0.9. Hb 12.7, plts 323.
4/24/25: A1c <5.7. Vitamin D47. TSH 1.22. Vit B12 539. Hb 12.3, plts 331. Cr 0.63. T bili 0.7, AST 74, ALT 98, alk phos 385. Cholesterol 147, triglycerides 66, LDL 68.
4/29/25: HEPATIC FUNCTION PANEL - Alk phos 385; AST 47; ALT 83.
5/6/25: Abdominal ultrasound: Subtle increased liver echogenicity may represent steatosis. Large simple cyst in the upper pole right kidney; Normal barium esophagram.
6/30/25: CT abd/pelvis w contrast: Steatotic liver disease. 3 cm right hepatic nodule. No acute findings.
7/14/2025 - Fibroscan Results - CAP 282, kPa 4.4
7/30/25: EGD/colonoscopy: LA Class A esophagitis in the lower third of the esophagus. Hiatal Hernia. Gastric food. Normal mucosa in the duodenum. Furrows in the whole esophagus compatible with eosinophilic esophagitis. (Biopsy). Erythema in the whole stomach compatible with gastritis. (Biopsy). Internal hemorrhoids. Mild diverticulosis of the left colon. 1 polyp (3 mm) in the cecum. (Polypectomy). Otherwise normal colonoscopy to cecum. Biopsies with Esophageal eosinophilia (30/HPF). Minimal chronic gastritis. C TA x1 (7y).

Assessment:
# Chronic constipation: Improved on Linzess.
# Alk phos elevation: Noted on labs 3/2025. Repeat labs with persistently elevated alk phos. Abdominal ultrasound with findings of subtle increased liver echogenicity. FibroScan with fatty liver without evidence of scarring or fibrosis. Will continue to monitor/trend. Will try to obtain recent repeat labs.
# History of diverticulitis 2/2025. Reviewed colonoscopy in 2019. Recommend colonoscopy for further evaluation and she ld like to proceed.
# Dysphagia: Esophagram was normal. EGD with findings of esophagitis, hiatal hernia. Symptoms are improved on PPI. She is currently asymptomatic.
# EoE: Seen on recent esophageal biopsies. She will continue PPI therapy.
# Chronic clopidogrel
# Epigastric pain: GERD, esophagitis, medications, gastroparesis, constipation may be contributing.  Most recent 6/2025 without acute findings. EGD with gastric food, gastritis, hiatal hernia, esophagitis, path with EoE and chronic gastritis. Colonoscopy with internal hemorrhoids, mild diverticulosis or the left colon, cecal colon polyp. Symptoms are improved on once daily PPI but not resolved. Discussed trial of twice daily PPI and she is agreeable to trying. Also discussed diet modifications and eating small, frequent meals. She declined gastric emptying study.
# GERD: Advised to avoid common GERD triggers.
# History of colon polyps: On colonoscopy 7/2025, patient with removal of a cecal tubular adenoma. Recommend repeat colonoscopy in 7 years.
# Fatty liver: Seen on abdominal ultrasound. FibroScan with fatty liver without scarring or fibrosis. Risk factors include elevated BMI, hypertension, hyperlipidemia. Labs with elevated alk phos. She is losing weight on Wegovy.
Plan:
pantoprazole 40 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth twice a day before breakfast and dinner
Eat small meal portions
Continue current medications
My office will obtain prior lab results
Avoid swallowing large pieces of food, dry bread, especially meat. Wash pills down with plenty of fluids.
Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Follow-up with P.A./N.P. in 2 months
Additional Notes:
Please notify patient that gastric biopsies with minimal inflammation. 2. Esophageal biopsies with eosinophilia which could be related to reflux or possible allergic process. Recommend continuing trial of pantoprazole. 3. Colon polyp was an adenoma; recommend repeat colonoscopy in 7 years.

UC

Diagnoses:
Ulcerative colitis (chronic), pancolitis without complications (c, IBD)
Erythema nodosum
Assessment:
42 y/o F with ulcerative colitis on Humira, transferring care from Wichita Falls. She has not been seen in TDDC previously.  She has developed erythema nodosum.  I can't tell for sure if that's because she now has subclinical Crohn's Disease, or if she has a UC flare without her typical symptoms, or if she is having a reaction from the Humira itself.  In any of those cases, the treatment of choice would be switching her medications.  Discussed a variety of options, and she would like to try Rinvoq.  Labs ordered today.  Will check humira Ab to look for evidence of immunogenicity.  May need to avoid TNF-alpha class for now while Humira is in question.  Pre-biologic labs ordered.  Switch advil to celebrex.

Chief Complaint:
Hospital Follow Up
History of Present Illness:
Cordelia Bailey is a 82 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.  This is a follow-up visit for Cordelia Bailey regarding a recent hospitalization for acute pancreatitis. The patient was seen in the hospital on 08/13/2025, at which time they were diagnosed with acute pancreatitis and a pancreatic pseudocyst. There was also a dilated pancreatic duct and intrapancreatic ductal system noted. The gallbladder was surgically removed during that admission as it was suspected to be the cause of the pancreatitis. Currently, the patient reports feeling well and that the pain has completely resolved. They are active and walk between 6,000 and 9,000 steps per day. The patient no longer experiences acid reflux and is managing this with diet alone, without medication. There is no longer any constipation; however, they now experience some diarrhea and fecal urgency. The urgency varies depending on the time of day and dietary intake. The patient reports attempting to eat a healthier diet but does not wish to eliminate meat entirely. The patient denies hematemesis, melena, hematochezia, nausea, vomiting, dysphagia, odynophagia, unexplained weight loss, fever, and chills. An abdominal ultrasound was performed on 08/13/2025. A subsequent magnetic resonance imaging scan was performed to rule out stones in the bile duct, and this was negative. The imaging did show a pancreas with significant inflammatory changes and the development of cysts, presumed to be pseudocysts secondary to the pancreatitis. The past medical history is significant for acute pancreatitis in August 2025, cholecystectomy in August 2025, acid reflux, and constipation, which has resolved.

Assessment:
Discussed in detail with the patient regarding their CT-Abdomen/Pelvis results. Discussed in detail with the patient regarding their MRI/MRCP results. Discussed in detail with the patient regarding ultrasound results. Discussed in detail with patient lab results. I have discussed with patient in detail the current diagnosis and differential diagnosis.
1. Acute pancreatitis, K85.90
- assessment: resolved.
- Investigations planned for Issue 1: A repeat magnetic resonance imaging scan of the pancreas will be ordered in approximately one month to monitor the pseudocysts and ensure they are shrinking, and to rule out true cysts which carry a cancer potential. The patient was counseled that a computed tomography scan is an alternative but has more radiation exposure. A complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel will also be performed.
- Treatment planned for Issue 1: The current plan is observation, as the patient is asymptomatic and the pseudocysts are expected to resolve over several months.
- List medications prescribed or discussed, with instructions: No new medications were prescribed.
2. Diarrhea, R19.7
- assessment: likely post-cholecystectomy diarrhea.
- Treatment planned for Issue 2: Continue to monitor symptoms.
- List medications prescribed or discussed, with instructions: No new medications were prescribed.
3. Pancreatic pseudocyst, K86.3
- assessment: pancreatic pseudocyst.
- Investigations planned for Issue 3: A repeat magnetic resonance imaging scan will be performed in approximately one month.
- Treatment planned for Issue 3: We will continue to monitor with the expectation that these will resolve spontaneously over time.
- List medications prescribed or discussed, with instructions: No new medications were prescribed.
A follow-up appointment is scheduled in approximately two months to review the results of the laboratory work and imaging, and to ensure continued recovery. The patient was informed that the purpose of surveillance is to ensure the pseudocysts, thought to be from inflammation, are resolving. It was explained that this process can take several months. An order for a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel was placed, and the patient was given a requisition. The process to obtain pre-authorization for the magnetic resonance imaging scan was explained.
Plan:
Continue current medications
GERD diet, education provided
Complete Blood Count (CBC) with Diff
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP)
MRI Abdomen/Attention: Pancreas/With and WITHOUT contrast - 74183
Follow-up office visit in 2 months
Additional Notes:
The level of service for this established patient visit is determined to be a level 4 (99214). The medical decision making was of moderate complexity. This was a follow-up visit for a patient with a recent hospitalization for acute pancreatitis with a complication of a pancreatic pseudocyst. The assessment and plan involved reviewing past imaging, ordering new imaging (magnetic resonance imaging), ordering laboratory tests, and discussing the natural history and potential risks, including the small possibility of the cysts being true cysts with malignant potential. The management of these problems required a detailed discussion and coordination of further diagnostic studies, justifying a moderate level of complexity.

Assessment:
Terry Williams is a 78F who presents with acute on chronic constipation, which is most likely exacerbated by decreased mobility after she suffered from a fall in May 2025 and her mobility has significantly decreased. Conservative OTC measures have not provided relief except for enemas. Fecal impaction was manually disrupted in clinic today but was quite proximal however a small amount of light brown stool was able to be extracted. Discussed with patient's son who states he will try to do an enema at home today. Will send in prescription for Golytely bowel prep to manage this acute exacerbation. Pt and son instructed that she does not have to finish the entire gallon if she is having bowel movements and feeling better. Will also start Linzess 72 mcg daily given lack of response to conservative management. Encouraged 64 oz of water daily however we discussed that constipation may continue to be a recurring problem especially with her mobility status and she may need enemas PRN. Pt's son verbalizes understanding. Will also obtain CT scan and proceed with diagnostic colonoscopy. I will need records from most recent lab work, medication list and recent hospitalizations prior to proceeding with colonoscopy. Will also need to obtain cardiac clearance prior to colonoscopy. ED precautions discussed including but not limited to worsening abdominal pain, fevers, progressive nausea/vomiting, blood in stool. Pt and son verbalize understanding.
Plan:
Golytely 236-22.74-6.74-5.86 gram Drink 1 kit by mouth split dose as directed for colonoscopy prep
Linzess 72 mcg Take 1 capsule by mouth, on an empty stomach, at least 30 minutes before a meal, ~same time each day
CT Abdomen and Pelvis with oral and IV contrast

Chief Complaint:
Follow Up EGD, Ultrasound
History of Present Illness:
Shaylin Longoria is a 25 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. This is a follow-up for a 25-year-old female previously evaluated on 08/20/2025 for lower abdominal pain with alternating constipation and diarrhea.
The primary complaint today is isolated nausea, which has been present since the age of 11. The nausea is somewhat improved today. It occurs approximately once daily, typically in the morning and mid-afternoon. Taking ondansetron helps alleviate the symptom. There is a history of being sick at age 11, potentially due to reflux, and a proton pump inhibitor was trialed at that time, but the effectiveness is not recalled.
The right-sided abdominal pain persists; however, the location has changed. It was previously in the right upper quadrant and has recently shifted to the right lower quadrant, with the pain alternating between these two locations. The pain occurs approximately three to four times per week, lasts for about three minutes, and is described as a sharp ache. Rubbing the area provides some relief. The severity has decreased since its onset in August, now rated as a three out of ten. There is no prior history of similar pain.
Symptoms of reflux are reported approximately three times per week, occurring mainly at night.
The previously reported alternating constipation and diarrhea has resolved, and there is now only constipation. Bowel movements occur every three days with hard stools. This is possibly exacerbated by the use of ondansetron.
The review of systems is negative for hematemesis, melena, hematochezia, diarrhea, vomiting, dysphagia, odynophagia, fecal urgency, unexplained weight loss, fever, and chills. Nausea and constipation are present as noted above.
An upper endoscopy performed on 08/22/2025 revealed non-erosive gastritis. Pathology was negative for celiac disease and Helicobacter pylori but was positive for reactive gastropathy. An abdominal ultrasound on 08/21/2025 was unremarkable, showing no evidence of gallstones or biliary ductal dilation. A complete blood count from 08/20/2025 showed an elevated white blood cell count of 12,000 cells per microliter and elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit of 15.7 g/dL and 47% respectively, suggesting possible dehydration. Repeat laboratory studies on 08/25/2025 were within normal limits. A computed tomography scan of the abdomen and pelvis performed in the emergency room in mid-August was unremarkable, showing only a small amount of physiologic free fluid in the pelvis.
The past medical history is significant for non-erosive gastritis and reactive gastropathy.
PAST SUMMARY: 08/20/2025
Shaylin Longoria is a 25 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit. The individual presents for evaluation of lifelong stomach issues, characterized by persistent nausea and an upset stomach, described as a queasy and nervous sensation, which has been thought to be associated with a history of anxiety. The symptoms acutely worsened approximately one week ago, last Monday, with the onset of significant nausea that prevented the ability to eat or drink anything. Over the past two days, there has been a slight improvement, with the ability to consume small amounts of solid food. This recent episode prompted two visits to the emergency room, where no definitive cause was identified.
The recent episode was associated with mild, sharp, right lower quadrant abdominal pain. There was also a poor appetite and an associated symptom of experiencing white flashes upon standing up. The nausea is exacerbated by sweet foods, with a current tolerance limited to vegetables and similar items. There has been no vomiting associated with this recent episode. The individual reports a history of both constipation and diarrhea, which are equally bothersome. These symptoms have been present since childhood and have occurred long before any history of marijuana use, which has been discontinued for some time. The chronic nature of these symptoms has a significant impact on daily life.
The individual denies hematemesis, melena, hematochezia, dysphagia, odynophagia, fecal urgency, unexplained weight loss, fever, and chills.
Laboratory studies from 08/16/2025 at HCA Clear Lake revealed a normal lipase level and a normal magnesium level. The basic metabolic panel was unremarkable, with normal kidney function, electrolytes, and blood glucose levels. There was a mild elevation in the white blood cell count to 11.3, which could be indicative of a transient infection or dehydration. The liver panel was normal. A computed tomography scan of the abdomen and pelvis performed on the same date showed a small amount of pelvic fluid, which was considered likely physiologic and not a cause for alarm.
The past medical history is significant for anxiety. The individual has a history of marijuana use but reports not having used it for a while.

1. Gastroesophageal reflux disease, K21.9
- Assessment: Gastroesophageal reflux disease
- Investigations planned for Issue 1: None at this time.
- Treatment planned for Issue 1: A trial of omeprazole for two weeks was recommended. The GERD diet was reviewed and discussed.
- List medications prescribed or discussed, with instructions: Omeprazole 20 milligrams once daily. She was counseled on the potential side effects of proton pump inhibitors.
2. Abdominal pain, R10.9
- Assessment: Nonspecific abdominal pain
- Investigations planned for Issue 2: A hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan with cholecystokinin stimulation was offered to evaluate for gallbladder dysfunction if right upper quadrant pain persists. A colonoscopy was offered to evaluate the colon as a source of the new right lower quadrant pain. She has deferred further testing at this time to first see if regulating bowel movements improves the pain.
- Treatment planned for Issue 2: She will continue a high-fiber diet and increase water intake. She was advised to minimize the use of ondansetron due to its constipating effects. The option for over-the-counter or prescribed stool softeners was discussed if needed. She declined medications for constipation at this time.
3. Nausea, R11.0
- Assessment: Nausea
- Treatment planned for Issue 3: The nausea may be related to poorly controlled reflux, and it will be reassessed after a trial of omeprazole. The importance of not relying on nausea medication long-term was discussed. She declined a trial of metoclopramide.
Shaylin Longoria is a 25-year-old female here for a follow-up of abdominal pain, nausea, and altered bowel habits. Her upper endoscopy and abdominal ultrasound were largely unremarkable, showing only mild, non-specific gastritis. The thought is that her initial severe symptoms may have been related to an acute infectious process, such as gastroenteritis, with associated dehydration, from which she is having a prolonged recovery. The current plan is to address her reflux symptoms with omeprazole, as this may also be contributing to her nausea. She will also focus on managing constipation with a high-fiber diet and increased fluid intake to see if this alleviates her lower abdominal pain. Further diagnostic testing, including a hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan and colonoscopy, were offered but she has chosen to defer these for now. We will re-evaluate in approximately six weeks.
Plan:
omeprazole 20 mg Take 1 capsule by mouth once a day, 30 minutes before the first meal of the day
High fiber diet, education provided
Continue current medications
GERD diet, education provided
Potential side effects of a PPI were discussed with patient regarding long-term safety.
Follow-up office visit in 6 weeks
Politely declined bowel regimen at this moment.
Patient declined colonoscopy and HIDA scan with CCK

Chief Complaint:
Colorectal first visit- rectal pain x 6 months
Referral from Sean Neufeldt
History of Present Illness:
Ayman Alasad is a 49 year old male patient who is seen today for an initial visit.
This is a 49-year-old male patient here to see me for evaluation of anorectal pain. He presents with a six-month history of constant rectal pain, which he describes as a burning or stabbing sensation. The pain is present at rest, rated as 5/10, and feels slightly worse on the left side. It is exacerbated by prolonged sitting but only slightly worsens with bowel movements.
He reports a history of hemorrhoids since age 17. He underwent a hemorrhoidectomy in 1997. Following the procedure, he had intermittent prolapsing hemorrhoids requiring manual reduction. In 2019, he underwent a colonoscopy with Dr. Olson for increased pain, at which time he had hemorrhoidal banding performed. The procedure provided relief for approximately two years. The hemorrhoids began to prolapse again about two and a half years ago, but this was painless until the onset of the current pain six months ago. He notes that in the past, he experienced some bleeding associated with the prolapse about a year ago, but denies any recent or significant bleeding. He denies constipation, abdominal pain, pencil-thin stools, or unintentional weight loss. He reports adherence to a high-fiber diet and good bowel habits, spending only 1 to 2 minutes on the toilet per bowel movement. He denies a history of anemia.
His past medical history is significant for hemorrhoids. His past surgical history includes a hemorrhoidectomy in 1997. He had a colonoscopy with hemorrhoidal banding in 2019, which was otherwise normal.
Test results reviewed:
He reports having done a Cologuard test recently which he reports was negative. The 2019 colonoscopy report was reviewed and noted to be normal, with a recommendation for a repeat in 10 years (2029).
Physical exam:
External anorectal inspection reveals a chronic posterior midline anal fissure with associated scar tissue. There was no internal examination performed due to anticipated severe pain.

Assessment:
1. Chronic Anal Fissure: The clinical presentation of burning, stabbing rectal pain at rest, exacerbated by sitting, in combination with the physical exam finding of a chronic-appearing posterior midline fissure with scar tissue, is consistent with this diagnosis. The pain is likely attributable to the fissure itself and associated hypertonicity of the internal anal sphincter muscle.
Plan:
- A trial of medical management is initiated.
- A colonoscopy is recommended in approximately four weeks to fully evaluate the anorectal canal, assess for underlying hemorrhoidal disease, and perform colorectal cancer screening. This will also serve as a follow-up to assess his response to medical therapy. He will be traveling for three to four months starting in four weeks, and we will attempt to schedule the procedure before his departure.
- The risks and benefits, preparation, and procedural details were discussed and any questions were answered.
- Medical treatment planned: Nifedipine ointment, a compounded calcium channel blocker, to be applied as a pea-sized amount to the external anal area three times daily. This is intended to increase local blood flow and relax the internal anal sphincter to promote healing. The prescription will be sent to Daniel Drug.
- Lifestyle modifications: Recommended to take warm sitz baths for 10 to 15 minutes, 2-3 times per day to help relax the anal sphincter muscle and increase blood flow. He is to continue his current high-fiber diet and avoidance of straining.
- Follow-up appointments: He will follow up for a colonoscopy in approximately four weeks. If he is not improved, surgical intervention including fissurectomy with Botox injection will be considered.
Plan:
Colonoscopy with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 45378
Additional Notes:
After Visit Summary:
- Your visit today was for rectal pain. The examination showed that you have a chronic anal fissure. This is a non-healing wound that is causing your pain, likely due to muscle spasms
- We will start with medical treatment to try and heal the fissure. This includes a special compounded ointment and warm baths.
- Nifedipine ointment: Please apply a pea-sized amount of this ointment to the outside of your anal area three times a day. We have sent the prescription to a compounding pharmacy called Daniel Drug, and they will have it ready for you. This medication may take about two weeks to start working.
- Sitz Baths: Please soak in a warm to hot bathtub for 10-15 minutes at least twice a day. This helps relax the muscles and improves blood flow to help with healing. You do not need to add Epsom salts unless you find it makes you feel better.
- Diet: Continue your excellent high-fiber diet and habits of avoiding straining or long periods on the toilet.
- We also discussed having a colonoscopy in about 2-4 weeks, before you leave for your travels. This will allow us to examine the area fully under sedation, check on your hemorrhoids, and make sure your colon is healthy. If you cannot have a colonoscopy before your travels, we would like to see you in the office before you leave.

Assessment:
This is a patient with a prior history of GERD with fundoplication, small bowel intussusceptions he presents after having a self-limited episode of severe abdominal pain.
She also has issues with ongoing GERD symptoms.
Will obtain her prior records from her retired gastroenterologist.
We will proceed with an upper endoscopy with possible dilation given her dysphagia evaluate for any strictures, Barrett's esophagus. To be evaluate her fundoplication to see if it is intact.
In the meantime she should continue with GERD lifestyle and diet modifications, and as needed Tums and Pepcid.
Will proceed with a screening colonoscopy with ileal intubation.
Thank it is reasonable to proceed with an MR enterography to evaluate for any small bowel lesions or strictures given her intussusceptions and bowel obstructions.
Further management pending above

Chief Complaint:
follow up on colonoscopy
History of Present Illness:
Judy is a 71 yo female here today for follow up on EGD/colonoscopy completed on 05/14/2025. Results from EGD showed chronic gastritis, suspicion for Barrett's esophagus, esophageal mucosal changes suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis, normal duodenum; biopsy revealed mild chronic inactive gastritis, negative for H. pylori. Colonoscopy showed bowel prep fair, non-bleeding internal hemorrhoids, perianal hemorrhoids, 7-9 mm polyp in transverse colon, redundant colon. Pathology revealed tubular adenoma transverse colon. She will need another colonoscopy in one year (05/2026) due to suboptimal colon prep. Encouraged high fiber diet; started on pantoprazole 40 mg daily.
Today she reports that she is doing well. She is taking the pantoprazole daily and her Gerd symptoms are well controlled. She has history of osteopenia and is taking daily calcium and vit D3 to mitigate adverse effects of PPI use. She denies dysphagia, nausea, vomiting, heartburn. Denies abdominal pain. Chronic constipation with IBS, on daily Linzess a mcg. Daily BM. Denies diarrhea or other change in bowel habits. Denies hematochezia and melena.

Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain and constipation
History of Present Illness:
Josephine Smith is a 75-year-old female in for office visit with complaints of constipation, right upper quadrant fullness and acid reflux. Per chart review, she last saw Dr. Bracey for office visit in January 2019 for complaints of intermittent chest pain with palpitations. Her GERD was noted to be under control with pantoprazole twice daily. She was advised for follow-up in 6 months. She last had EGD and colonoscopy in October 2021 for GERD, history of colon polyps. Findings were small hiatal hernia, mild distal esophagitis with biopsy back as mild nonspecific changes. Mild erosive gastritis negative for H. pylori. Normal duodenum. Mild colonic diverticulosis. 4 hyperplastic polyps removed. Small internal hemorrhoids noted. Next colonoscopy is due next year.
She states that she has been having issues with constipation for which she used to take MiraLAX years ago, but it caused her to have lower back cramping, so she stopped it. She has started drinking prune juice as of late, but it caused her to have loose stools. However, she does have relief of the constipation. She has associated abdominal bloating. No nausea or vomiting. She has also noticed right upper quadrant fullness that has been consistent over the past couple of months. She denies any melena, hematochezia or unintentional weight loss. She reports having indigestion with certain foods namely eggs in the morning. She takes Tums for this. She has weaned herself off of Nexium and takes it as needed at the advice of her doctor. She has a history of osteopenia. She also reports noticing a right lower back area with a lump gets bigger when she is constipated, but she drinks when the constipation is relieved.

Assessment:
This is a 75-year-old female in for office visit with complaints of constipation, right side abdominal fullness with RLQ tenderness on exam and indigestion. Will obtain CT abdomen pelvis for further evaluation. She is no longer taking Nexium at the advice of her doctor, but tends to use it as needed. Will try famotidine instead. Advised for trial of Metamucil and to increase her water intake. Also discussed adding align probiotic.
Plan:
CT Abdomen and Pelvis WITH ORAL and IV contrast - 74177
famotidine 40 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth once a day
For the constipation, get Metamucil fiber capsules. Take 2 capsules once a day with a full 8 oz glass of water.
Increase your water intake to at least 64 oz of water daily.
Get Align probiotic bloating relief + food digestion capsules. Take 1 capsule daily with food.
Stop esomeprazole magnesium 40 mg no longer taking regularly

Chief Complaint:
cough
History of Present Illness:
Catherine Batiste is a 74 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last seen in 2023. She is here with complaints of cough for the past 6 months. She reports this occurs intermittently about every 2 months. She reports this is mostly nocturnal. Her cough is non-productive. She did see ENT for this. She has been on Pantoprazole 40mg every other day for about a year. She has been on loratadine intermittently for the past year but she does not find this helps her cough. She does note regurgitating at night. She does note intermittent burning in her throat depending on what she eats/drinks (alcohol, caffeine). She denies eating late. She denies NSAID use. Amlodipine and Losartan are in her external medication rec, but she states she is not taking them. She denies dysphagia, nausea, vomiting, and epigastric pain. EGD 2018 with small hiatal hernia. She has a bowel movement daily or every other day that is formed. She does note loose stools if she eats dairy or drinks too many smoothies. She denies overt GI bleeding, watery diarrhea, constipation, and lower abdominal pain. Colonoscopy 2023 with diverticulosis, otherwise unremarkable. Recall set for 2028 but she is unsure if she wants to proceed at that time. She denies unintentional weight loss. Her father had colon cancer.

Assessment:
Intermittent non-productive cough, mostly nocturnal, that presented 6 months ago. She does note intermittent regurgitation and reflux at times despite QOD PPI. EGD 2018 with small HH. She did see ENT a few months ago for this. Amlodipine and Losartan are in her external medication rec, but she states she is not taking them. We discussed that these medications may have a side effect of a cough. Colonoscopy recall changed from 10 years to 5 due to father's history of colon cancer. Colonoscopy 2023 unremarkable.
Plan:
Start taking Pantoprazole once daily in the morning rather than every other day.
famotidine 40 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth at bedtime
Acid reflux in adults, patient education materials generated by EMR
My office will obtain prior records from Southern ENT.
Do not eat 3 hours before laying down.
Eat small, frequent meals
Prop head of bed at 30 degrees
Follow-up office visit in 2 months
Call office with any questions or concerns.
